data.title: The 17 Best Movies That Are Set In Cairo
data.meta_description: Cairo, a city woven with history and mystery, serves as the perfect backdrop for many cinematic adventures. From thrilling chases through bustling markets to ...
data.text:
Cairo, a city woven with history and mystery, serves as the perfect backdrop for many cinematic adventures. From thrilling chases through bustling markets to romantic encounters by the Nile, films set in Cairo capture a unique blend of ancient allure and modern vibrancy. These movies not only showcase the city's iconic landscapes but also delve into its rich cultural tapestry, offering viewers an immersive experience that goes beyond typical tourist snapshots.

The films selected for this list are celebrated not just for their entertainment value but also for how they represent Cairo’s multifaceted character. Each movie provides a different perspective on life in one of the world's oldest cities, whether through drama, comedy, or suspense. As you explore these cinematic gems that highlight Cairo’s enchanting chaos and serene beauty, feel free to vote on your favorites to help shape this list into an even more definitive guide.

1

7 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: Classic comedy meets ancient horror as Abbot and Costello's bumbling antics take them through Egypt's perilous pyramids, culminating in a chaotic and hilarious showdown with a resurrected mummy.

Summary:

Abbott and Costello Meet the Mummy is a 1955 film directed by Charles Lamont and starring the comedy team of Abbott and Costello. It is also the 28th and final Abbott and Costello film produced by Universal-International.

Actors : Lou Costello, Bud Abbott, Richard Deacon, Michael Ansara, Marie Windsor

Released : 1955

Directed by : Charles Lamont

2

11 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: Cairo's iconic landscapes turn into a battlefield, making for an unforgettable sequence that mixes puppet mayhem with global geopolitics.

Summary:

In the audacious satire Team America: World Police, an elite group of puppet operatives, led by Gary Johnston (Trey Parker), are on a mission to save the world. This unconventional squad, comprised of Lisa (Kristen Miller), Chris (Matt Stone), and others, battles global threats from North Korea to Hollywood. Co-created by South Park's Trey Parker and Matt Stone, this film uniquely combines marionette-based visual storytelling with political commentary. Despite its comedic appearance, it offers a sharp critique on American foreign policy and celebrity culture. The movie is known for its iconic songs and memorable one-liners that contribute to its cult status.

Actors : Trey Parker, Matt Stone, Kristen Miller, Masasa Moyo, Daran Norris

Released : 2004

Directed by : Trey Parker, Matt Stone

3

7 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: In the heart of Cairo, a gritty neo-noir murder mystery unfolds, revealing the dark underbelly of corruption and power, set against the backdrop of the labyrinthine streets and opulent palaces of the city.

Summary:

A police officer in Cairo investigates the murder of a famous club singer at the Nile Hilton Hotel. What initially seems to be a crime of passion turns into something that concerns the power elite of Egypt.

Actors : Fares Fares, Mari Malek, Yasser Ali Maher, Slimane Dazi, Ahmed Selim

Released : 2017

Directed by : Tarik Saleh

4

5 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: Satirical spy shenanigans ensue as OSS 117, the suave yet clueless secret agent, navigates the entangled web of Cold War politics and espionage, set against Cairo's historic and bustling backdrop.

Summary:

In this spy movie parody, French Office of Strategic Services agent Hubert Bonisseur de La Bath (Jean Dujardin) investigates the disappearance of his fellow agent and longtime friend Jack Jefferson (Philippe Lefebvre). Disguised as the head of a wholesale chicken company, Hubert dispatches to Cairo amid the Suez Crisis. He meets his contact, Mossad agent Larmina El Akmar Betouche (Bérénice Bejo), but then comically stumbles upon an international conspiracy.

Actors : Jean Dujardin, Bérénice Bejo, Aure Atika, Philippe Lefebvre, Constantin Alexandrov

Released : 2006

Directed by : Michel Hazanavicius

5

11 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: Star-studded satire blends Hollywood glitz and Cairo grit, as a cunning con artist masquerades as a film director to execute a daring heist, turning Egypt's vibrant locales into a cinematic playground of deception.

Summary:

In order to receive a fortune in stolen gold bullion, master criminal Aldo "The Fox" Vanucci (Peter Sellers) needs a coastal location. So he poses as a famous movie director, using his drop-off point, a sleepy Italian town, as the "setting" for a new production. But the shrewd plan threatens to come undone thanks to Vanucci's movie-mad sister, Gina Romantica (Britt Ekland), and the fictional production's star: egocentric, nearly forgotten matinee idol Tony Powell (Victor Mature).

Actors : Peter Sellers, Victor Mature, Britt Ekland, Martin Balsam, Akim Tamiroff

Released : 1966

Directed by : Vittorio De Sica

6

12 VOTES

The Cairo Connection: Epic spectacle meets historical drama as the construction of a grand pyramid turns into a tale of power, betrayal, and forbidden love, with Egypt's timeless landscapes serving as the majestic stage for this ancient saga.

Summary:

Obsessed with his fate in the afterlife, the egotistical Pharaoh Khufu (Jack Hawkins) recruits oppressed architect Vashtar (James Robertson Justice) and forces him to design the most lavish and well-secured pyramid ever built. Vashtar struggles to meet Khufu's lofty expectations, knowing that, if he does so, the ruler will release his enslaved brethren from bondage. As construction begins, Khufu's new wife, Princess Nellifer (Joan Collins), plots to secure her own piece of the tyrant's riches.

Actors : Jack Hawkins, Joan Collins, Dewey Martin, James Robertson Justice, Alex Minotis

Released : 1955

Directed by : Howard Hawks
